thread.title: UK Weather: Tomorrow set to be hottest February 20th for 160 years | Metro News
thread.title_full: UK Weather: Tomorrow set to be hottest February 20th for 160 years | Metro News

author: Tanveer Mann For Metro.Co.Uk
title: UK Weather: Tomorrow set to be hottest February 20th for 160 years | Metro News
text:
Tanveer Mann for Metro.co.uk Sunday 19 Feb 2017 10:38 am Finally, some warmth! (Picture: PA) 
Spring seems to be edging ever closer with tomorrow looking set to be the hottest February 20th for 160 years. Caribbean hot air is going to bring weather hotter than the Mediterranean 
Temperatures are expected to reach 16C which will be hotter than even Greece, Dubai and Saudi Arabia at this time and the hottest since February 20, 1857. 
The warmth is all thanks to a ‘blast of hot air from the Caribbean’, which many will see as a welcome change from last week’s bitter cold temperatures. Temperatures are expected to reach 16C tomorrow (Picture: PA) 
The hottest recorded day in February was in 1998, when thermometers reached 19.7C. 
A Met Office spokesperson reportedly said Monday will be one of the warmest February days since February 23, 2012, when temperatures reached 18.7C in northern Wales. 
Forecaster Helen Roberts told Metro.co.uk: ‘It is going to be very mild for the time of year tomorrow but it is more scientifically correct to look at February as a whole.’ 
‘Yesterday we saw temperatures of 15.1 in north west Wales, which was the highest of the year and today we’re likely to see similar temperatures, more across southern counties. 
MORE: Dog keeps abandoned toddler alive in freezing weather It is expected to be the hottest February 20th in 160 years (Picture: Rex) 
‘Temperatures will hit 15C this afternoon and tomorrow we will see the peak of the particularly mild air. Once a year the sunset lines up to make Yosemite National Park’s waterfall glow like it’s on fire 
‘We’re looking at highs of 16C close to London and in the east Anglia region. 
The highest temperatures are likely to hit Aberdeen, Wattisham and London, with the east of the country enjoying most of the warmth. More
